document.docAuthor: Barahona-Segovia, Rodrigo M., Riera, Pamela, Pañinao-Monsálvez, Laura, Guzmán, Vicente Valdés & Henríquez-Piskulich, Patricia
document.masterDocTitle: Updating the knowledge of the flower flies (Diptera: Syrphidae) from Chile: Illustrated catalog, extinction risk and biological notes

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Updating the knowledge of the flower flies (Diptera: Syrphidae) from Chile: Illustrated catalog, extinction risk and biological notes

figureCitation.captionText: FIGURES 51–54. Meromacrus laconicus (Walker, 1852): (51) lateral view; scale bar = 0.25 mm; (52) head, frontal view; scale bar = 0.1 mm; (53) dorsal view; scale bar = 0.25 mm, and (54) wing; scale bar = 0.25 mm. Photos by Patricia Henríquez.

bibRefCitation.author: Sack, P.
bibRefCitation.refString: Sack, P. (1920) Die Gattungen Salpingogaster Schinerund Meromacrus Rondani. Zoologische Jahrbucher, Abteilung fur Systematik, Geographie und Biologieder Tiere, 43, 235 - 272.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type locality and data.
“ Brazil ” (T, ♀ , BMNH )
.

Material examined. Arica y Parinacota :
1♂ , Lluta , km 31,
13.XII.1979
, Leg. G. Días P. ( UTA ); 1♀ , Lluta , km 40
, Tarapacá Province ,
21.I.1968
, Leg. R.H. González ( MEUC ); 1♀ , Azapa , Km 12,
20.III.1980
, Leg. G. Díaz P. ( UTA ); 1♀ , Azapa , Km 12,
3.I.1977
, Leg. H
. Vargas ( UTA ).
World distribution. Brazil , Colombia , Costa Rica , Ecuador , Guyana , Panamá , Paraguay , United States , Venezuela and Chile .
Chilean distribution. Only recorded from Arica y Parinacota region ( Fig. 55 ).

Altitudinal range. This species inhabits transverse valleys between 80 and
500 m .
a.s.l.

Biology and notes.
Meromacrus laconicus
is here reported from Chile for the first time. The genus
Meromacrus
is distributed from the southern United States to northern Argentina (Sierra Madre to Chacoan province; Morrone, 2014 ). Thompson et al. (2010) recorded the genus from northern Chile without citing any particular species. Considering the collection site, it is associated with crops and semi-natural environments. This species is widely distributed in South America and Chile , probably is the most southern distributional record. Therefore, it should be classified as a Least Concern species. The larvae have been recorded recycling organic material in rot-hole trees and bromeliads (
Blatch et al. 2003
). Adults visit flowers of tropical fruit trees in rainforests or crops (
Blatch et al. 2003
).
Conservation status. LC; EOO = 14 km 2 ; AOO = 12 km 2 (see biology and notes for explanaition).
